told the court they felt a jury
would be more difficult to select
this time than for the first trial
which ended in hung jury Feb.
7. A special venire of 200 jurors
was used for the first trial.


Beckwith has been in Jail since
FBI agents arrested him June %
at Greenwood. Hendrick declared
a mistrial last month when the
l2-man all white jury reported
it was hopelessly deadlocked
after ii hours of deliberation.

Martha Chapter No. l held a
St. Patricks Day Tea at Ma
iestic Hall. Mrs. Ora Jackson
was general chairman.


Grand worthy matron Savara
Nelson received a fraternity COL
lar with all degrees from the
Lily Of the Valley chapter Of
Mesa.


Mrs. Naomi Fisher is the
worthy matron and Mary Jane
Freeman Is the chapter secre-
tary.


St. Johns Grand Lodge enjoyed
a sunrise breakfast at Majestic
Hall, 1906 South Ninth Ave.. Mar.
y.


Mrs. Roosevelt Mary Jones
surprised her husband with
birthday luncheon.


Guests included Mr.. and Mrs.
Alfred Williams, Mr.. and Mrs.
Robert Cherry. MIR. and Mrs.
Wesley Jackson, Sgt. and Mrs.
Booker Sanders, Charles Felter,
Mrs. Mayfair Dunlap, Mr.. and
Mrs. John Wilson, MIR. and Mrs.
Ernest Reddington, Mrs. Lille
M. Hall and Mrs. Ora Jackson.


St. Johns Day was celebrated
at Lone Star Baptist Church,
1920 South III Ave.. Sum. Mar.
u.


Mesdames Ardelia Wilson, Alb
bey Austin and G. Nj. Alfred
Moore participated.


Rev. C. V. Nelson delivered
the sermon. A choir from Mesa
provided the music.

JACKSON, Miss. Circuit
Judge Leon Hendrick set April
6 as the date of a new trial
for Byron de la Beckwith. &C
cused of Staying Negro civil
rights leader Medgar Evers.


The process of drawing a 300
man special venire for Beck
with's second trial was started
Immediately.


Both Dist. Atty. William Wal
lar and Beckwith' s attorneys
Hardy Lott and Stanny Sanders

XENIA, Ohio Barber Lewis
Cegner announced he has closed
his Yellow Springs shop indef-
initely following mass demon
strations protesting his refusal
TO cut the hair of Negroes.


Cegner said his shop will re-
main closed and he will take no
further action until the Ohio Su-
premem Court acts on his appeal

from an appellate court ruling
which held that his refusal to
cut Negroes hair was in vio-
lation of the states public &C
commodation law.


In the meantime, the barber
said, he intends to find out
what Antioch, Central State and
Wilberforce colleges plan to do
about students breaking the
